Description: Papyrus (three fragments) written with black ink with demotic administrative text on recto: frag. A: 8 ll.; frag. B: 8 ll.; frag. C: 12 ll. List of tombs. The fragments belonged most likely to the same document. Nos.10522-10532 and 10535-10537 belonging to the same archive, cf. P. BM EA 10522.
Curator's comments: This document is part of a family archive associated with Panas, son of Espmetis, a mortuary priest and moneylender. Panas’ archive contains documents from his own business (between 180-157 BC), his father Espmetis’ business (between 239-223 BC) and Panas’ wife Tathoytis (from 175 BC). Papyri from Panas’ archive are held by multiple institutions, the British Museum holdings are: EA10388; EA10532; EA10556,1-4; EA10557; EA10612; EA10613; EA10614; EA10615,1-3; EA10670,1-7; EA10823 and EA10824. Panas also appears in documentation from other family archives, including that of Pechytes, son of Pchorchonsis, and what is known as the ‘Anonymous’ family archive. For a full list of associated documents and their relationship with Panas: https://www.trismegistos.org/arch/archives/pdf/446.pdf https://www.trismegistos.org/arch/detail.php?quick=446 P.W. Pestman, 1995. ‘A family archive which changes history’, in S.P. Vleeming Hundred-gated Thebes: acts of a colloquium on Thebes and the Theban area in the Graeco-Roman period B. Muhs, 2005. Tax receipts, taxpayers, and taxes in early Ptolemaic Thebes
Bibliographic references: Andrews 1990a / Catalogue of Demotic Papyri in the British Museum IV: Ptolemaic Legal Texts from the Theban Area (p.74-5, pl.62)
